## R Packages


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

:::


-   rcistats
-   tidyverse

# Palmer Penguins

## Palmer Penguins


::: {.columns}
::: {.column}

The `penguins` data set was contains information on penguins from the [Palmer Station](https://lternet.edu/site/palmer-antarctica-lter/) located in . You can learn more about the data set [here](https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/articles/intro.html).

:::
::: {.column}
![Artwork by @allison_horst](img/penguins.png){fig-alt="An image of several penguins in Antartica."}

:::
::: 

## Variables of Interest

- `flipper_len`: Flipper Length in [millimeters](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Millimetre)
- `body_mass`: Body mass in [grams](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gram)

# Describing numerical data

## What is numerical data?


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="true"}
penguins |> 
  slice(1:7) |> 
  pull(flipper_len)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
#> [1] 181 186 195 193 190 181 195
```


:::
:::



## Central Tendency


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="true"}
penguins |> 
  slice(1:7) |> 
  pull(flipper_len)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
#> [1] 181 186 195 193 190 181 195
```


:::
:::




## Variation


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="true"}
penguins |> 
  slice(1:7) |> 
  pull(flipper_len)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
#> [1] 181 186 195 193 190 181 195
```


:::
:::



# Summary Statistics

## Summary Statistics

Summary statistics are used to describe the distribution of data.

## Central Tendency

Central tendency is a statistical concept that refers to the central or typical value around which a set of data points tends to cluster. It is used to summarize and describe a data set by identifying a single representative value that provides insights into the data's overall characteristics.

## Variation

Variation in statistics refers to the extent to which data points in a dataset deviate or differ from a central tendency measure. Understanding variation is crucial for making informed decisions, drawing meaningful conclusions, and assessing the reliability of statistical analyses.

## Minimum

The minimum (min) is the smallest value in the data.

## Maximum

The maximum (max) is the largest value in the data.

## Quartiles

Quartiles are three values (Q1, Q2, Q3) that divides the data into four subsets.

::: fragment
![](https://i.postimg.cc/p2BbKK5t/image.png){fig-align="center"}
:::

## Q1

Q1 is the value signifying that a quarter of the data (25%) is lower than it.


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-5-1.png){fig-align='center' fig-alt='A density plot of flipper length for each penguin.
The lower 25% of the of the density plot is shaded.
This shading represents the location to the 25th percentile.' width=960}
:::
:::



## Q2 - Median ($\tilde{x}$)

Q2 is the value signifying that half of the data (50%) is below it.

::: fragment
The median also represents the central tendency of the data.
:::


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-6-1.png){fig-align='center' fig-alt='A density plot of flipper length for each penguin.
The lower 50% of the of the density plot is shaded.
This shading represents the location to the 50th percentile.' width=960}
:::
:::




## Q3

Q3 is the value signifying that 3 quarters (75%) of the data is below it.




::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-7-1.png){fig-align='center' fig-alt='A density plot of flipper length for each penguin.
The lower 75% of the of the density plot is shaded.
This shading represents the location to the 75th percentile.' width=960}
:::
:::




## Interquartile Range


$$
IQR = Q_3 - Q_1
$$



::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){fig-align='center' fig-alt='A density plot of flipper length for each penguin.
The middle 50% of the data is shaded.
This shading represents interquartile range.' width=960}
:::
:::


## Range

::: fragment
$$
R = \mathrm{max} - \mathrm{min}
$$
:::

## How to identify the quartiles?

1.  Sort the data
2.  ID Max and Min
3.  Find the amount of data the makes a quarter:
    1.  $K=N/4$
4.  Create 4 groups using the sorted data
    1.  group by data size
    2.  If $K$ has a decimal, the $Kth$ value is quartile of each group.

## Mean ($\bar{x}$)

Describe how you will find the mean of these numbers:


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
#> [1] 18 18 12 18 13
```


:::
:::


## Mean ($\bar{x}$)

The mean is another measurement for central tendency.

$$
\bar X = \frac{1}{n}\sum^n_{i=1}X_i
$$

-   $n$: total data points

-   $X_i$: data points

-   $i$: indexing data

-   $\sum$: add all from first (bottom) to last (up)

## Variance

The variance is a measurement on the average squared distance the data points are from the central tendency.

$$
s^2 = \frac{1}{n-1}\sum^n_{i=1}(X_i-\bar X)^2
$$

## Standard Deviation

The standard deviation is a measurement on the average distance the data points are from the central tendency.

$$
s=\sqrt{s^2}
$$


## Mean vs Median

::: {.columns}
::: {.column}

### Mean

$$
\bar X = \frac{1}{n}\sum^n_{i=1}x_i
$$

:::
::: {.column}

### Median

$$
P(X \leq \tilde{X}) = 0.5
$$


:::
:::

## Mean vs Median

Mean (blue line) vs Median (red line)


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){fig-align='center' fig-alt='A density plot of flipper length for each penguin.
The mean and median are repsesented as vertical lines.
The mean is located at approximately 201.
The median is located at approximately 197.' width=960}
:::
:::


## Outliers

These are data points that seem to be highly distant from all other variables.

::: fragment
![](https://miro.medium.com/v2/resize:fit:697/0*_k9tUMfs2P4CGUA3.png){fig-alt="An image of a scatter plot with the points following an exponential curve. One point is far from the curve." fig-align="center"}
:::

# Numerical Statistics in R

## Numerical Statistics in R

R has several built in functions to compute statistics.


## Mean

```r
mean(DATA$VAR)
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)

## Median

```r
median(DATA$VAR)
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)

## Standard Deviation

```r
sd(DATA$VAR)
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)

## Variance

```r
var(DATA$VAR)
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)

## Quartiles

```r
quantile(DATA$VAR, probs = c(0.25, 0.5, 0.75))
```
- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)

## Max and Min

```r
max(DATA$VAR)
min(DATA$VAR)
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)

## Summary Statistics

```r
rnum_stats(DATA$VAR)
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)

## Penguins 


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="show"}
num_stats(penguins$flipper_len)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
#>   min q25    mean median q75 max     sd     var iqr missing
#> 1 172 190 200.967    197 213 231 14.016 196.442  23       0
```


:::
:::


# Data Visualization

## Histogram

A histogram is a graphical representation of the distribution or frequency of data points in a dataset. It provides a visual way to understand the shape, central tendency, and spread of a dataset by dividing the data into intervals or bins and showing how many data points fall into each bin as a bar.

## Histogram R Code

```r
ggplot(DATA, aes(VAR)) +
  geom_histogram()
```

To change bins:

```r
ggplot(DATA, aes(VAR)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = VAL)
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)
- `VAL`: Numerical value to change the bin width.

## Histogram


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="true"}
y <- rnorm(1000)
ggplot(tibble(y), aes(y)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 15)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-12-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Histogram


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="true"}
y <- rgamma(1000, 2)
ggplot(tibble(y), aes(y)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 15)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-13-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Histograms


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="true"}
y <- rbeta(1000, 5, 1)
ggplot(tibble(y), aes(y)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 15)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-14-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Histograms


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="true"}
y <- rbinom(1000, 1, 0.4)
z <- (y == 0) * rnorm(1000, 23) + (y == 1) * rnorm(1000, 27)
ggplot(tibble(z), aes(z)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 15)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-15-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Penguins


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="false"}
ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_len)) +
  geom_histogram()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-16-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Box Plot

A box plot, also known as a box-and-whisker plot, is a graphical representation of the distribution and key statistical characteristics of a dataset. It provides a visual summary of the data's central tendency, spread, and potential outliers.

## Box Plot

![](https://miro.medium.com/max/9000/1*2c21SkzJMf3frPXPAR_gZA.png){fig-align="center"}

## Box Plot R Code

```r
ggplot(DATA, aes(VAR)) +
  geom_boxplot()
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)

## Box Plot


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="false"}
ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_len)) +
  geom_boxplot() 
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-17-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Box Plot


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="false"}
ggplot(penguins, aes(y = flipper_len)) +
  geom_boxplot() 
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-18-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Dot Plots

Dot Plots are similar to histograms, but they incorporate dots to count how many data points fall within bins.

## Dot Plots in R

```r
ggplot(DATA, aes(VAR)) +
  geom_dotplot()
```

To change binwidth

```r
ggplot(DATA, aes(VAR)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth = VAL)
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)
- `VAL`: Numerical value to change the bin width.

## Dot Plots


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="false"}
ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_len)) +
  geom_dotplot(binwidth = 1)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-19-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Density Plot

## Density Plot

A density plot is a way to visualize the distribution of a continuous variable â€” it shows where data values are concentrated (dense) and where they are sparse via the height of the graph.

## Density Plot in R

```r
ggplot(DATA, aes(VAR)) +
  geom_density()
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)


## Density Plot


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="false"}
ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_len)) +
  geom_density() 
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-20-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Adding Vertical Lines

```r
ggplot(DATA, aes(VAR)) +
  geom_density() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = XVAL)
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)
- `XVAL`: Number to place the vertical line (eg: `5`)


## Vertical Lines


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="false"}
ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_len)) +
  geom_density() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = mean(penguins$flipper_len), col  = "blue") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = median(penguins$flipper_len), col = "red")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-21-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Adding Horizontal Lines

```r
ggplot(DATA, aes(VAR)) +
  geom_density() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = YVAL)
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR`: Name of the variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)
- `YVAL`: Number to place the horizontal line (eg: `2`)

## Horizontal Lines


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="false"}
ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_len)) +
  geom_density() +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0.01, col  = "blue") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 0.02, col = "red")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-22-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::




# Skeweness

## Skeweness

Skewness is a statistical measure to determine if unimodal data follows a symmetric distribution, skewed to the left, or skewed to the right.

## Symmetric Distribution

A symmetric distribution will look bell shaped and the mean (red line) and median (dashed blue line) will overlap each other.


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="true"}
y <- rnorm(100000)
ggplot(tibble(y), aes(y)) +
  geom_density() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = mean(y), col = "red") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = median(y), col = "blue", lty = 2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-23-1.png){fig-align='center' fig-alt='A bell shaped curve where the mean and the median are represented as lines and overlap each other.' width=960}
:::
:::


## Right Skewed Distribution


A right skewed distribution looks asymetric and the mean (red line) is to the right of the median (dashed blue line).


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="true"}
y <- rgamma(100000, shape = 4)
ggplot(tibble(y), aes(y)) +
  geom_density() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = mean(y), col = "red") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = median(y), col = "blue", lty = 2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-24-1.png){fig-align='center' fig-alt='A bell shaped curve where the mean and the median are represented as lines and overlap each other.' width=960}
:::
:::


## left Skewed Distribution


A left skewed distribution looks asymetric and the mean (red line) is to the left of the median (dashed blue line).


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="true"}
y <- rbeta(100000, shape1 = 5, shape2 = 1.25)
ggplot(tibble(y), aes(y)) +
  geom_density() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = mean(y), col = "red") +
  geom_vline(xintercept = median(y), col = "blue", lty = 2)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-25-1.png){fig-align='center' fig-alt='A bell shaped curve where the mean and the median are represented as lines and overlap each other.' width=960}
:::
:::



# Scatter Plots

## Scatter Plots

Scatter plots demonstrate how two variables behave with each other. They can tell you any postive or negative trends, if they exist, with the combination of the plots.

## Positive Relationship


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-26-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Negative Relationship


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## No Relationship


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Weak Relationship


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}
::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-29-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::


## Scatter Plots in R

```r
ggplot(DATA, aes(x = VAR1, y = VAR2)) +
  geom_point()
```

- `DATA`: Name of the data frame (eg: `penguins`)
- `VAR1`: Name of the X variable to create a plot (eg: `flipper_len`)
- `VAR2`: Name of the Y variable to create a plot (eg: `body_mass`)

## Penguins


::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code  code-fold="show"}
ggplot(penguins, aes(flipper_len, body_mass)) +
  geom_point()
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](3_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-30-1.png){fig-align='center' width=960}
:::
:::

include-after-body:
<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
